qNow7fBWCwcslyX3GSHV7Q.text: If I could give zero stars I would. The food was bad. The service was terrible. The servers were rude. Then the manager refused to apologize for the service.

3LVkVDGw__mAh2UrpL2i9g.text: I was expecting a lot more from The Big Chill House to be honest. It has some fantastic PR and when I pitched up here I really thought that I was going to have a good time.... Perhaps it was the time that my friends and I turned up - 2.30am on a weekend night. Now, I would have thought that this was a perfectly acceptable time to pitch up for a reasonably big club like this, but it felt like everyone was closing up and going home! I bet you all know this feeling, when the barmen look like they would rather be tucked up in bed (I can't blame them), and the comfy lounging sofas are doubling up as beds for all the tired customers. The place was also half empty, which didn't help the cause much. Our group decided to see if there was anywhere in the club which had more going on, but were slightly disappointed to find that it was also smaller then we expected. We stayed around on the dance floor for a bit before calling it a night. I think for the sake of fair and even journalism I should come back and give it a shot at a less ungodly hour.

3CjkwrSGNOF2UEhlpr7mog.text: This is a sort of large pub vibe, but with a sort of dance floor. Felt a bit like a student's union, but not particulairly in a bad way. Music was not bad, and the drinks were standard. Good beer garden / smoking terrace on the roof. Free before 10pm, so get there early! One of the better bars in the Kings X area; id fully recommend it for all you students living around there.

nnwKcLxZnuruQD4Wl05IpA.text: I think Gry was overly harsh with her 3/5! I know the drinks selection isn't perfect, but the Aspinal's Suffolk cider is eminently drinkable on a summer's afternoon. It's like a maze in here. Lots of small balcony areas with cushions on the floor, big central dancefloor and bar, upstairs club and roof terrace too. The food isn't bad either. The best thing about the big chill house (showing its festival roots) though, is the music. I've been to an all day sunday band session, several great club nights and seen coldcut live - which was one of my best nights out ever! The place is so small that you can chat to the dj's and bands during and after their sets... check out the photos :)

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom

6i5co3z4NVejrUEoPu6S7Q.text: I absolutely adore the Big Chill House in Kings Crossand not just because it's close by to where i live, though that helps. During the week and early weekends the main bar area is free. It is a wide a space with a mezzanine area whichcan be booked for parties. At weekends the rest of the venue opens up with an upstairs bar, a heated outdoor area and some seating sections downstairs in the basement. As the main area is already quite big it means that the place can really attract the crowds and have a good time. The bar area is large, the staff are excellent, as are their range of drinks and cocktails. Service is quite fast and entrance after 9pm at weekends is not too expensive. That the venue is situated right by the tube makes it a great place to have a party or meet a large crowd without worrying about travelling home.

WV08FHvehhR_G5BkwPpHSg.text: Great, really well priced and put together cocktail menu (champagne cocktails from £6 a pop)... only down side being it can take bloody ages to get served sometimes. Bouncers can be a bit full on too. Otherwise a great venue that's always been doing a really interesting mix of music (much more eclectic than most places) and arts with regular comedy nights. Still not that much in the surrounding area but definitely getting better.

xPAWbvZNDGekzd1Xi2CYnw.text: To be fair I had a few too many drinks before I came here a couple of weeks ago on a Friday! There was a small queue of about 5 people to get in which didn't take long and your hand is stamped as you go in so you don't have to worry about not being able to get back in. I think it was £5.00 to get in and we got there at about 1 am so it's pretty cheap. Once we got in we only had to wait about 5 mins to get served, not too sure how much the drinks were though - I had gone past caring by that point. As I had never been there before myself and my boyfriend and I decided to go and explore! We walked around the different levels and rooms, unfortunately excluding the terrace as you can't take drinks there! It was a really nice place, we had a few drinks, did a bit of dancing, had a chat and met some great new people. The place genrally has a good atmosphere and I look forward to going there again!

2zidrQWSh1iqbHBNg1sZJg.text: The Big Chill House is a good place to meet in Kings Cross, as it is very close to the station. It is very spacious with three floors, and is always open late. It has got a bit of a reputation amongst people who like a quieter night as it can get extremely busy and rowdy on a weekend, especially later on, but in general the atmosphere is good. A redeeming feature is the first class music they put on, often for free on a sunday afternoon. Lots of the stars of the modern folk scene play sets, the DJs are fantastic and it can feel like a cool festival once you turn your back on the view of pentonville road! My preference is to check out the music, but if you like your night busy, loud and manic, then friday is for you!

RVe3PYsXS0w-O8jkclBI1Q.text: Big Chill Bar in King cross Worse to worse We been invited by our boss at the Big chill in kings crossfor our annual Christmas party (14 guess) Our boss was waiting more then 20 minutes just to make anorder, when he call the barman to let him know that the waiting time was a bitlong the barman because aggressive and at the end refuse to serve him. The situation was unreal The aggressive barman start to talk to an Australian barmanwho refuses to serve him because is was the flatmate of the aggressive barman bla bla bla where are we going here whoooo!!!! Is not finish, they call the security because it was anunrealistic situation  security been call against someone not drank but spokethe truth Our boss has been ask to explain him self outside, came back after 5 minutes without problem accept one bar staff who treat himwith is finger on is throat. It is look that the little Mafia behind the bar can do whatthey want and they don't mean to prejudice this bar reputation at all. The share owner will need to wake up urgently. Olivier Reed catering Consultant

bNz96e6pL8AVdyzagmGSXg.text: The big chill house, situated right next to Kings Cross St Pancras is in a great location . I have to admit that the drinks are not cheap but as expected for the area. The downstairs is great for listening to music and getting on the dance floor but Have to say my favourite part of my night here was the outside smoking area which is placed on the rooftop, it does take a little while to get out there if it is a busy night but I would definitly recommend a visit!!

-Kaw590GyUXu_2uhA14ABg.text: It must be that Londoners have a different understanding of the word "chill" because my (American) friends and I found ourselves a bit overstimulated during our time in the Big Chill House. I am giving it three stars because, as far as clubs go (and on the weekends, TBCH is definitely more like a club than anything else), this one is indeed "A-OK." I'll reiterate again that my friends and I were not looking for a club that night, but had heard that the conveniently-located Big Chill House was a good place to drink beer. It's neither chill, nor a good place to drink beer (unless you like drinking £4 Heineken in a club whose clientele is--as I'll later explain--a bit skewed, age-wise). I thought about giving it one or two stars, but then realized that such a low rating would have been more about my (apparently misguided) expectations than about the place itself.As I said, insofar as it is a club, it's really not a bad one. I don't really prefer the dominant club scene here in London, and have been to some awful clubs where I couldn't escape the shitty music or the constant and suffocating presence of sweaty, drunk lads. On the other hand, the Big Chill House seemed different:  the interior hosts a number of nooks and tucked-away seating, and you can always distance yourself from the bar and the music if you so desire. The different levels are not just like mezzanines that overlook a main space below but instead have a separate, secluded feel. The more modern-aesthetic of second level offers a VIP kind of space for lounging around with I guess whoever you lounge around with in a VIP kind of space. When I went, this section was reserved for a private party. Too bad. Those chair/booth/lounger/bed things looked comfortable. The music the DJ was playing wasn't so bad. It wasn't good either, but plenty of people were dancing. The clientele were what was truly bizarre. Some friends had stopped by a couple weekends ago and mentioned that the crowd seemed a bit older than us:  late twenties/early thirties. We arrived expecting something similar, but with a twist:  there were also a strange amount of very young-looking people. Were they really eighteen? Maybe they just looked and acted like eighteen-year-olds? People were clearly enjoying themselves. I think I saw one booth take probably seventy digital pictures in less than three minutes. One drunk thirtysomething guy had a stuffed shark whose hand (er, fin?) he was forcing everyone to high five. Needless to say, as students in our early 20s looking for something truly chill (i.e. a place that was less-crowded with quieter music but still a lively enough for some good beer-drinking and conversation) we felt out of place and left after one pint. The end. They're open from what must be 7 a.m. until 4 a.m. every day, because I always see people in there for breakfast or lunch or evening pints. Maybe I'll go back during one of those times.

mObRI9ho65YPEaXM5F1lHA.text: The Big Chill House looks somewhat rough and dodgy from the outside, and you might see lots of trendy-looking men in skinny jeans go inside, but don't let that stop you. It's got a pleasant atmosphere, laidback but cool. The main area is spacious and open, but there are several other rooms to explore (apparently there is a special Finlandia room somewhere in the basement!). But best of all, there's a really great terrace! According to some dude in Time Out the bar's got a 'cutting-edge selection of spirits', but the selection of what's on tap is pretty meagre: Heineken and Guinness. And cider. It's also pretty expensive. So I guess they're mostly catering for the weekend crowd (there are also lots of DJ events here). Still, though, the fabulous terrace makes it a worthwhile place to go for an after-work drink if you're in the neighbourhood.

py2rygsmjRYy-Xj8NAEgeQ.text: Best thing about this place is the outside roof terrace, where summer and drink can equal fun times. There are lots of hidden nooks and crannies inside if the weather betrays you, and plenty of cushions to collapse on. The surroundings outside are a bit rough if you're trying to impress someone though, so perhaps not ideal for a first date. They do good chips.

sbQ76whf7OaFOsZg9iyPoQ.text: I think that Big Chill is a great space with a good atmosphere, but I found them a bit inflexible when we turned up at 4pm one day quite peckish and were told that we couldn't even order a bowl of chips to go with our drinks. Surely it could not be too hard for them to have some bar snacks available all day.

ZlhXLSwMhsj370qne4fGMw.text: Pretty cool atmosphere, good drinks, decent looking food, and some excellent music at times. However, the staff can be pretty unfriendly at times - especially the door guys They can afford to be, because it's so popular, but it's still not a good attitude to have.. but anyway, on the whole it's a really good venue for a night out. The decor is really cool too.

OTxPosTOP-hL63UvDvnucg.text: Situated on one of the busiest roads in Kings Cross escape the traffic fumes and venture inside. This is the sister venture of the Big Chill Bar in East London and has a similar theme. The venue is large and is split over three floors, food is reasonable and décor is original if a little under whelming. The big cachet here is the terrace where you can enjoy your drinks under the sun, despite being in the heart of the Cross it does have a certain Iberian feel which is often aided by the DJs. This place stays open late and they have different events on most nights. I cant imagine coming up here solely for this bar but if you are in the vicinity it is worth a visit. For locals the Sunday Brunch is excellent value for money and exactly what the doctor ordered if you have over done it the night before.

XstC0Rng0_4K3T6EEmnUmw.text: Great DJ's and good line up of music for chilling out, very mixed clientele, bit scruffy, average place, not a brilliant location, not somewhere I would go out of my way to visit again

htVkC8DhbVHXXK2ExgE1iA.text: Some friends and I stumbled across The Big Chill House when wandering around Kings Cross looking for a bar before a gig and we were pleasantly surprised.The drinks were your average London prices, around £5 for a pint, but i a cool venue like this I didn't mind so much!We headed up to the roof terrace which was packed, so we wandered back inside and found the games room which was empty!Yes, it was totally epic, and I suck a table football!  The decor was awesome and for being a warm day was very well air conditioned!   We spent a good hour playing games and drinking before we had to leave, I'd of willing spent all night there!I will certainly be returning!

_eLYhxSX1MXCZOw-7Gopyg.text: A wee bit on the pricey side, but we can forgive that, especially in the summer when you can get on that roof!

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom. The roof, the roof!

IxyvHpMCiF7q8CrrWVmyZg.text: 5/5 for the food - I had the vegetarian breakfast and it really was delicious, plus incredibly cheap. Drinks less affordable, but then it is centrally located in Kings Cross.It's a big place but takes bookings, which is handy if meeting with a group.I went at 2pm on a Sunday and it was pretty quiet - it has filled out more by the time I left at around 5.30 though. Very nice roof terrace, particularly good for sunny weather.

lhSszUUFuZOmwr0wsUFlvA.text: The times I have gone in were when the place was not really packed and less than half full - so take my words with a grain of salt.The place is pretty huge for a bar/pub area, presumably for drunken dancing.  For the nights that I have gone, the music was a little off for me -- and a bit too loud for my tastes.  I had to yell over the music when we were ways away from the speakers.  They have quite a nice seating area upstairs that is a little bit more intimate, with comfortable couches + pillows - probably a good place to take a date.  As for the crowd, it's a mixed bag - college students, young professionals, and older.  They are, for the most part, laid back.The best part is, though, going upstairs and onto the roof if its open.  You can overlook some of the city (the building is quite short actually), and have a great conversation whilst admiring London.I took a star off for the quirky choice in music and the expensive drinks.

iXHpO7EMSvnmh5r0dmHBtA.text: Great venue with lots of attitude.I love all the graffiti and the odd mirror details in the bathroom.Staff aren't the friendliest and is on the expensive side. However if you want a 'trendy' place to hang out in Kings Cross  this would be it!At night it can sometimes get really busy and noisy however it's open really late which is a plus!

yHWVWOBVQlPSs5EMMMZplQ.text: Unusual place to go. Eatery downstairs. Chill out games room on the first floor and roof terrace when the sun shines. Pint of cider up here went down very well

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom. Roof terrace

cFtLFfcnIcFlCIgtQQivvA.text: Relaxed vibe during the day, nice roof deck.Bartenders were very chill, and they serve a decent burger. Not much else to report.

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom. Classic Burger

wGV490Pliu8TG1Ucfa3qeA.text: long story short: cold fries, cold burger, cold beans - save your time and don't come here!the only positive thing to say is that the poor selection of beers was at least cold too.

HQQLMR6FZWSLPpHCRJIwHg.text: If this place were empty, the vibe might have been really weird as it's kind of a cavernous establishment. As it was, we stopped in early Friday evening and it was bustling. The beer was good, the atmoshpere was lively, and the barstaff was available despite the crowd. Will definitely stop in again soon.If you're nearby for comedy at the Invisible Dot, it's a good meeting place!

EH2fo5LoYmFRxvRyyWZI1A.text: Great place to chat with friends on a Sunday afternoon/evening as it was pretty quiet. Food was great and really good value with a taste card. Drinks were a little on the pricey side. They also poured a large glass when asked for a small and although they gave me 10% off the price of a large, I can't help but feel it's their way of upselling. Maybe a genuine mistake but it's happened before there. I'm sure they would give a small if insisted, but watch out for it.

NKA8udSo4qH5xawAbahEfw.text: This is a pretty cool venue but the drinks are quite expensive (though I suppose that can be said everywhere in London). Solid french fries / chips though!

aV5HYRaIwMGE8-GFiOCRSQ.text: Always a good place to hangout on a weeknight. Always a chill vibe, weird music though on some nights. Drink specials are great though.

Q7vWkRdP7gjZ2N9JA02b3w.text: We had a very weird night here a few weeks ago, it was a Sunday night and the next day was a bank holiday so they had some kind of night on. We got there about 8 ish and were the only people in the place for about 2 hours but the music was still turned up full, so we needed to shout in each others ears even though we were sat next to each other on the sofa. We didn't mind that much though, we sort of enjoyed the surreality of the experience. The place reminds me quite a lot of a student union

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom

sOcJDGkA1fqUzlBrb5ySnw.text: Reggae night. I had no idea these words would mean booty-poppin' women in silver sequined ponchos (she looked like a Pokemon) and 4 feet-tall pimps in floor-length fur coats. As a side note, the drinks are ridiculously expensive. Although I guess that doesn't really matter though; if you're coming here to party, you're probably trashed out of your mind on White Strike anyway.

1rTB7kH--Hek3lLegAIBBw.text: The Big Chill House is the flagship venue of the Big Chill enterprise which has grown to include not only its fantastic record label, which helped launch world famous artists like Zero 7, but a second smaller bar venue, and an increasingly popular music venue.Like everything else associated with Big Chill, The Big Chill House aims to provide relaxation musically, physically and spiritually.  Located only a short walk away from King's Cross tube station The Big Chill House isn't as large as you might expect but, depending on when you go, this can make the place feel nice and intimate.  Soothing lighting and uber comfy sofas really help you to unwind.  The drinks unsurprisingly are a little expensive but are of good quality and good variety.The best aspect of this club is undoubtedly the music.  Every night you are pretty much guaranteed to here something a little different and I have never been dissapointed by what was on offer.  Unlike other music venues I feel as if I could come here regardless of my mood.

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom

L7n_S-vjss5j6N38r9FBQQ.text: For a group of students living in the Kings Cross area, the Big Chill House has become the perfect bar and our backup plan if everything else fails.  The crowd is pretty laid back and full of people of all age groups and ethnicities which always ensures an interesting night.  On Thursdays through Saturdays there is a dj playing a good mix of music and the dance floor is always full.  Add their signature Big Chill Punch, and you and your friends are in for a guaranteed fun night.

ZYcCfnI5x6YTkMu6DgEn7Q.text: This place gets 2 just because of it's lovely roof terrace. If you can get a spot up here then you are well set as there is a bar up top too. It was a tad chilly when I was there but it was worth toughing it out. Downstairs met most items on my checklist for an unpleasant experiences. Ears bleeding? Check. Can't move? Check. Wallet empty after a couple of drinks? Check. I guess some people might suggest that it's because of my age that I can no longer enjoy umph umph umph umph music and shouting at my friends to make myself heard but I never really enjoyed this kind of place. I just didn't know what I did like back then. Now I do.so unless someone calls me from a prime spot on the roof, I will not be darkening these doors again.

N4JgUU_A3SgVjxJHA_qfRg.text: The Big Chill House is the mother bar of the Big Chill label.  Although I have found myself to be more than intrigued by the interior decoration of the bar, I have always felt a little uneasy about this place every time I have ventured here.  It is perhaps because I am still a bit young for it?  I have always felt that 'chill out' music is usually loved by the over-30s, but do correct me if I am wrong!It is located right next to King's Cross station which is very handy and easy to get to.  It has 3 floors, of which its best highlights include: the amazing south-facing roof terrace, the bean bags, a carbon fibre bar-top, vintage fold-out cinema chairs and a cosy Norwegian-themed room downstairs with a fake fire, a log cabin and seats that resemble beds more than anything else.  It is clear that a lot of time and money has been spent on the interior of this bar.  Other than that, it often organizes gig nights - usually not to my taste - and special Djs are often invited in to play.  The food looks good, but is overpriced just as the drinks are.  I guess it is worth a look, but I would not willingly spend a whole evening here.

spCWENJv5mdrJ_ue7NwY7Q.text: The Big Chill is an amazing laid-back friendly festival,and I was delighted when I heard it was opening a bar and club in London. I'm not sure what i imagined but it certainly wasn't this. It's a strange mish-mash of themes - there's a log-cabin-themed area downstairs complete with fake fires on screen, a Love Inn upstairs with leather pods to lounge in, and a roof terrace up top. The latter has a few great areas for groups, but is ruined by some incredibly uncomfortable benches and badly thought-out arrangement.I've been here for a couple of nights out and neither was amazing - the strange mix of styles leaves you feeling a bit lost and uncomfortable, and I wasn't a fan of the music either. If a funk/chill-out is your style though you might be onto a winner.My best visit was during the day, when the downstairs is more like a pub and does much better for it. The food is also terribly over-priced and you don't get much for your money. However, I did order an Irish Coffee here once, and the effort and time that went into it was amazing, and the taste matched, so I'd recommend the place for cocktails.

fD_oWDZRGUytTLAOXdwilA.text: The chicken strips are the best I've ever had! I got the Korean glaze sauce and it was spectacular. Tangy with a slight spice. Yum.

rHNp5BNTK3EkdzQEoK8tYg.text: This spot was not far from our hotel and we ended up coming here a couple of times. Each time was fun and they was some fun people watching here.Apparently this was a spot for the younger college-aged crowd but then again, there was a pretty good mix of older people about too.Really cool vibes here and they played the best music of any spot we visited during the week.

62ddGEBj3dMSAIXu852X_g.text: I was not aware that it was a club too.... I'm American, my mistake. I had a quick lunch here and it was great. Fish sandwich, fries, sorry, chips, and a coke for something like 5 pounds. Can't beat that!

V9pZBNMG45xQQKIBm9cl9Q.text: Drinks and music! Had fun time with friends! Personally liked the ginger cocktail! The blueberry one wasn't too bad.

bZUH55GP7qcICmBNxPaNKg.text: Wow. What a great little (actually big) spot! My friend Lauren had told me about this place 2 years ago and we decided to settle on it for our joint birthday party (yey). I email in and was easily able to reserve an area for 30 people. On arrival we were given the large area with a low ceiling to the right of the bar. It was perfect. The winning points to this place are it's large wrap around bar, huge dance floor, a decent amount of seating across three levels AND a mah-ussive beer garden. The beer garden will be awesome in summer and they do take reservations for it. NOTED.We grabbed a quick bite before everyone arrived. I opted for the £5 hot dog and some fries. For £5 the hot dog was good - a lovely, large bratwurst with plenty of ketchup and mustard and a soft bun. Bingo. The chips were good too - hot and perfectly salted. Quick, easy and cheap. I was happy. Then the night really commenced! Our guests began to arrive and everyone was happy with the area. The music was great, the only downside was that he kept mixing the songs. Sometimes we want to listen to a song all the way through you know. Never cut Bieber short! Lastly, the drink costs. £7.50 for a double absolute vodka and blackcurrent - I won't lie, it hurt every time I pulled our my cash card but that's me being Northern, and I guess these are London prices. We had a great night! We stayed until 3am and even that was too early. One last note, the bouncer on the door was lovely. We had a few really good chats. He was so friendly and chatty which is very rare for a bouncer.

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom. Chips for Bethany :)
Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom. 5 hot dog

-p-znwXp7P2gXv4WPP8r3A.text: Scenario: Yours truly is a glowing goddess of bronzed skin, having just returned from her tropical destination of choice, wearing a white T-Shirt, and her group of friends, including her unrequited love Baby decide it is time to unleash the tan upon the world, and shake the bronzed posterior in central London, and this place fit the brief. Reasonably priced drinks RnB musicNot too many humans tripping mad balls on ghb or molly, which is unlike London and very good newsand of course, Baby dancing like the perfect human he is to all of our favorite old school classics. Ah the glory! This place is actually quite big, what with a large terrace upstairs where you can go smoke, look into each other's eyes and wonder why you waited so long to finally get together ( the last bit didn't actually happen in real life, as my unrequited love cant even remember my name) But go try it out if you're central and need somewhere unpretentious and fun.

0mz0WEkcmY8D5gvAJwc8bw.text: Decent bar- located in a cool area near Kings Cross. We walked by and saw the big screen for the rugby but this is anything but a Sports bar. I think the best description is trendy hipster?!It's a good size with a lot of standing room and some table options. They do serve food which looked better than the normal pub food you might get elsewhere. Staff were friendly. The draft beers were pretty limited which was annoying but hey what can you do. Once the game was over... loud music came on and made it quit hard to have a conversation. The bar itself was busy and open late night. I would  go back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom

2GDCr6TRoPErESCHW6MH2A.text: Descent place, pretty girls everywhere, although beer was a bit flat, great music does tend to get a bit packed

_sej189CyyKtjJMQxreduQ.text: I hate the downstairs in this place, it's loud and full of knobs. Upstairs it's a different story, with a lovely roof terrace. The menu is just burgers and tacos. The burgers and chips are yum and the tacos tasty but tiny. They advertise cocktails behind the bar, but a White Russian my friend ordered as a birthday drink wasn't good at all. I also as a small female stood at the bar while three different groups of men arrived and got served.

x-AeXI-K5xHXt9ZpkjVHlQ.text: Big Chill House is exactly what the name says it is. After coming here for the first time on a Thursday after work I found it to be the perfect sanctuary for meeting up with friends which was what most people seemed to be doing there. I found this place after searching on Google bars with free WiFi. So I called them to to enquire if this was really true and it was. The drinks are fairly cheap (for London), good vibes, decor a bit funky and the staff were quite friendly. I booked a table and turned up a little early but got my table pretty much straight away. Feeling a bit pecking I ordered a burger. It was a blue cheese, caramelised onion and button mushrooms beef burger in a brioche bun. It was alright, not quite a good as it sounded on paper though. Plus it took quite a while to arrive at my table at which point I was getting impatient and wasting away over there. The music was on point, some classic tunes playing that one could sing along to (which I did). This place has a thumbs up from me.

16T2KF96JLtFn5-AMIIV7A.text: A-OK! This place got a lovely roof to chill at in a nice warm sunny day, or night. Also quite spacious in general.Been here for breakfast and happy hour. The breakfast food I've/ and my friends, have tried here are greek yogurt with granolas and berries- not exactly worth it, full english breakfast- which is quite big, some pastries- croissants and muffins, and continental style- which isn't worth it either. Nothing special really, although they do provide wifi here. Happy hour is good for shots and other kinds of cocktails. PS! Their sweet potato fries are yummy for the tummy!

886BtqcdH3D9Fik8kJcdsw.text: This place is ok, if nothing else is open. Beers good and the environment was chill (hence the name). But the service wasn't good. They were rather rude on several occasions.

HXyiXRLGXUGablULSozqnQ.text: Summer = rooftop, but London also equals Rain. But that did not dampen Isabel and I's spirit. Also, maybe I'm so used to city types because I work there, this place is not city at all, it's buzzing with media and fashion types which isn't a surprising as its so close to Shoreditch and Islington. I felt a bit out of place in my city girl heels and pencil skirt because everyone is super casual. Anyways, the bar itself on the rooftop is super tiny and seems to run out of supplies pretty fast and only one person is serving so if you can, you should get drinks downstairs first. Downstairs is massive, but I assume it doesn't really get lively til late and we were there for after work rooftop drinks- it's a bit sticky, and it's cheap, and a bit student so go with an open mind. I did walk past their drawing room and that looks super cosy but again, it was pretty empty when we went.You have to try their coconut and lime cider, it's like a lighter Malibu cocktail!The views: uh, not the best views in the city for sure, but you're there for cheap drinks and a makeshift rooftop tiki bar. Solid 3 stars.

d2sRQ3WUiFO8bJlumUJdiA.text: I went here for a Wray & Nephew Rum Tings night.The place was decorated with Wray items, There was a bbq upstair on the roof terrace offering jerk chicken,veg skewers. They had a selection of rum cocktails aswell as beer,wine etc.Its a nice venue mainly beacuse of the roof terrace for me but the rest of the place is like your normal bar. Clean toilets,cloakroom

ggRxcP2kO5CC9J5Q81kofg.text: This is going to sound like a weird review to most Yelpers but as you can tell by my nick name, I'm not one to worry about being unusual.The Big Chill House gets all the stars from me because it is where I host the monthly event London Vegan Drinks. Oh yes. Come upstairs at 257-259 Pentonville Road on the third Thursday of any month and you will find over 100 vegans and their friends drinking, eating and meeting without meat.The venue is full of character and the staff members are courteous and accommodating. Lovely range of bottled beers and ciders.*UPDATE* London Vegan Drinks doesn't take place here any longer. It is now at Whole Foods Market Kensington.

photos.caption: Photo of The Big Chill House - London, United Kingdom. Big Chill House on Pentonville Road

wjdg6J7G8Z0L6KahVg-cEw.text: I wish I could give this place 2.5 stars, because there's nothing exactly wrong with it, but "Meh. I've experienced better" pretty accurately sums up my sentiments towards this place. First, I should mention that I came here strictly for food on a Sunday evening, so my review may not speak to what you're looking for.I often pass the Big Chill on the way to school and wanted to give it a try. It's a roomy place, well-decorated, and a nice place to chat with your friends. The bartender (you have to walk up to the bar to order your food) was very sweet. The food, however, was very...meh. My friend and I shared the crab burger and the broccoli. The presentation of the food was great, and I really liked their fries, but the burger itself was lackluster, and the broccoli was nothing to squack about. In short, I think this place would be great if it had better food. As things stand, I don't think I would come back to eat here.

S7mm04gfaP7bSaylcgEWNQ.text: We made a booking here with a large group on a sunny Sunday in London. It is a great roof terrace, but the place clearly has some issues. Firstly, it smells like chemicals when you walk up the stairs onto the terrace... not sure what is going on there. Secondly, our server was incredibly rude. She literally made up house rules as she went. She was very unhappy with the fact that some of us wanted to start on drinks but order food later once everyone in our party had arrived, as the £15 bottomless mimosa / bloody marys are only supposed to be if you get food as well. Despite our assurances that we would order food once everyone had arrived, she was not happy. My friend had also asked when he made the booking if everyone at the table had to do the bottomless deal and was told no, but then she clearly thought otherwise and gave us some attitude until conceding that her colleague may have said otherwise because they JUST changed the rules. The mimosas themselves were good, with some legit orange pulp at least, but no one thought their drink was particularly alcoholic. On the flip side, they were reasonably attentive about refilling the drinks, as sometimes these bottomless deals can go terribly awry when they just slow down the service. As for the food, I think it also left a lot to be desired. I had the brunch burger and felt a bit sick afterward. The avocado toast looked awful... they'd done something to make the guacamole very runny. I wouldn't recommend anything we ordered, but I guess they make money because they make you get it with the drinks. The DJ was also playing music far too loudly, so it was difficult to have a conversation. This place has a lot of potential, but there are many better rooftops and beer gardens out there.

GK6jDlJAk3j6gfP87bvuYQ.text: This place I enjoy everyone. Ive been repeatedly over the past ten years.Good things. Its huge and midweek almost always a seat.It has a roof top bar... Before it was trendyThe drinks menu is largeIt has an ingenious way of letting you know your food is ready...Its a nice fun vibe without that pretentious Shoreditch vibeThe staff are always super friendly and jn a good moodTo be improvedThe menu isn't all thatThe place isn't well signed for newbiesToo little seating... But maybe that's good for evenings

beN-SNuOxFfp4wrcG0NT6Q.text: I feel like I shouldn't like this place, but I really do. Why shouldn't I like it? The name, truly a terrible name, and the exterior of the building makes it look like it's a hostel for Australians. But inside it's quite nice, roomy for friends to meet and the very best part is the roof terrace.We popped up to watch a film in their rooftop cinema and stopped off to have a drink at the bar. It's not a huge space but there's plenty of seating and they serve food and drink to your table. Pretty handy if you're kinda lazy, which I'm not, of course. Check out their weekly rooftop screenings of classic movies, it cost £3 and included the movie, a cocktail and some popcorn. They'll also deliver food and drinks to you during the movie.

IL_nrP3iE7eL-7k4zkc8Wg.text: Drinks date, on a roof top. Lovely. The sun was out on the vertical seedling roof garden and only a smattering of pollution and fags clouding my view between me and the flock of ripe young hot stuff trotting about in canvas espadrilles, I was reassured I'd have a chill time. With benches, drinks served in tin cans, boys with beards, grubby toilets, ironic retro tunes, overpriced drinks... *the sound of the needle slipping off the record*. No wonder it's called the Big Chill. You're gonna need to take a bloody chill-pill after ordering, £4.50 for a bottle of Meantime! Certainly was mean. Now as evening draws in I need something to warm my cockles, it's sunny spring in England and I'm underdressed for the plummet in temperature which the Big Chill has brought about my shoulders. Next time I'll be giving them the chilly cold shoulder darlings and heading to warmer climes.
